The practice of removing shoes when entering homes and certain buildings, like temples, is a common cultural practice in Korea and several other countries in Asia. There are several reasons why Koreans take off their shoes:

1. Keeping cleanliness: Keeping the floors free of dirt, dust, and other debris are essential in many Korean households. Since shoes are worn on the ground outside, they may carry dirt, germs, and other things that could make the floors inside the home unclean.

2. Respect: It is a sign of respect for the host's property to take off your shoes when entering their home or other places where it is expected. Koreans view shoes as something that belongs outside, while the inside of the home is considered sacred.

3. Tradition: The tradition of taking off shoes in Korea and other Asian countries dates back several centuries, and it has become deeply ingrained within the culture.

While it may seem inconvenient, taking off your shoes is an important part of Korean culture, and it can be a sign of politeness and respect to follow this cultural practice.
